ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

HOUSING LOANS OF CPF MEMBERS


    1. Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong asked the Acting Minister for Manpower what is

Column: 2591



    (i) the number of people who use all their incoming CPF contribution to pay for housing loans monthly; (ii) the amount of cash each of these individuals is required to top up for their housing loans once the total CPF contribution rate is cut to 30%; and (iii) the estimated impact of this reduction in cash circulation to our economy.

    The Acting Minister for Manpower (Dr Ng Eng Hen): Mr Speaker, Sir, as at 30th June this year, about 577,000 members (45% of total active members) serviced housing mortgage payments from their CPF accounts. Of these, 221,400 members (17.4% of total active members) had monthly mortgage payments that were equal to, or more than, their monthly Ordinary Account (OA) contributions. This represents the number of members who currently use all their incoming CPF contributions to pay for their monthly housing loan instalments.

    As for the Member's question on the amount of cash required to top up their housing loans once the CPF rates are cut and the estimated impact of reduction in cash circulation based on the CPF cuts, as the Prime Minister (PM) has yet to announce the changes, I will not be able to provide the specific details. I suggest to the Member that he may defer the questions after the PM has made the announcement.

INVESTMENT IN AND OUTFLOW FROM SINGAPORE


    2. Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong asked the Minister for Trade and Industry since 1997 (a) how many companies have migrated from Singapore to lower cost countries each year; (b) what is the amount of investment outflow from Singapore to these countries; and (c) what will be the estimated investment in and outflow from Singapore if the employer CPF contribution rate is cut by 6%.

    The Minister of State for Trade and Industry (Mr Raymond Lim Siang Keat) (for the Minister for Trade and Industry): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Government does not

Column: 2592

survey companies that are set up overseas without a presence in Singapore. As companies cease operations for many different reasons, the number of companies that have left Singapore for lower cost countries is not tracked.

    However, information on relocations is obtained from survey data in the Labour Market Survey, which covers private sector establishments with at least 25 workers. According to this survey, between 1998 and 2002, an average of 66 establishments each year had retrenched workers due to relocation. However, most of these companies retained a presence in Singapore.

Singapore Companies' Investments in Lower-Cost Countries

    Mr Steve Chia asked for the amount of investment outflow from Singapore to lower-cost countries. The stock of total direct investment by Singapore-based companies in China stood at $16.5 billion in 2001, an increase of $6.1 billion from that in 1997. For ASEAN countries, Singapore companies' total stock of direct investment was $26.8 billion in 2001, an increase of $8.1 billion from that in 1997.

    However, I would like to highlight that Singapore-based companies invest overseas for a variety of reasons, with cost-saving being one of them. A recent survey by IE Singapore suggests that, in addition to cost saving, much of the outward investment by Singapore-based companies is to increase sales by serving the growing customer base in these markets.

    Hence, investment outflows do not necessarily reflect `hollowing out' due to high costs. Often, it reflects the drive of our companies to internationalise. This drive will benefit Singapore firms in many ways - to expand into overseas market, to diversify their risk and revenue, and to upgrade their offerings of services and products.

    While some companies have scaled back operations in Singapore, there have also been investment inflows. For example, between 1997 and 2002, EDB

Column: 2593

managed to attract net investment commitments in the manufacturing sector worth $51.7 billion, of which $38.3 billion was foreign investment. Total business spending by foreign services firms was $7.4 billion over this period. As a result of these inflows, there has been a rise in the stock of net inward foreign direct investment.

    Mr Steve Chia, however, has raised a very important issue of the competition from lower-cost economies. Indeed, many new emerging economies, such as China and India, have improved their capabilities and the skills of their workers. Although our workers have better capabilities in many instances, if our costs are uncompetitive, many companies will relocate operations to lower-cost countries, and new investments would not come into Singapore. We would then eventually see a hollowing out of the Singapore economy. Jobs would be lost, and new jobs would not be created. It is therefore vital that we restructure our economy to meet these challenges.

Impact of CPF Cut on Investments

    Mr Chia asked what the estimated investment in and outflow from Singapore would be if the employer CPF contribution rate is cut by 6%. A CPF cut alone will not ensure that Singapore stays competitive. Nor can we quantify the impact of a cut in CPF rates in isolation from other measures to boost investments.

    The Economic Review Committee has addressed a wide range of issues that impinge on Singapore's competitiveness. These measures include external measures to enlarge our economic space, as well as internal measures to build new capabilities, invest in our people through education and training, and to ensure that our overall costs are competitive.

    Several measures have already been taken to lower costs. These include cuts in corporate and personal income tax rates, competition in the energy market and a programme of industrial land sales to ensure that our land costs are kept internationally competitive. The corporate tax

Column: 2594

rate has been cut to 22%, and will be brought down to 20% by 2005. Last year, the price of industrial space fell by 8%, while industrial space rentals fell by 7%.

    Wages constitute, on average, over a quarter of total business costs excluding the cost of materials and purchases. A reduction in CPF would lower the cost of doing business here. It would be an integral part of the comprehensive strategy to attract and retain investments in Singapore. More importantly, it would make our wage system more flexible, thereby making it easier for employers to hire workers when conditions improve. Taken together, these measures will enhance Singapore's attractiveness to investors. This will lead to more and better jobs for Singaporeans.

DISCONNECTION OF UTILITIES SUPPLIES
(Assistance schemes for affected households)


    3. Dr Mohamad Maliki bin Osman asked the Minister for Trade and Industry (a) what is the breakdown of the number of households whose utility supplies have been disconnected in the last six months, by flat size and the average period and amount for which these households have been in arrears; (b) whether SP Services Ltd will work with the Community Development Councils (CDCs) in making a proper assessment of the family's situation before deciding to disconnect their utility supplies; (c) whether for genuine financial hardship cases as assessed by the CDCs and social service agencies, SP Services Ltd will consider deferring their payments for the arrears and allow them to only pay the current charges until their financial situation improves or a reasonable period of time has elapsed; (d) whether SP Services Ltd will consider introducing a stored value system like those in the US and Britain to help Singaporeans take personal responsibility for their utility usage.

    The Minister of State for Trade and Industry (Dr Vivian Balakrishnan) (for the Minister for Trade and Industry): Mr Speaker, Sir, for water utilities, PUB's

Column: 2595

policy, since late 2002, has been to thimble the water supply instead of disconnecting it. There have therefore been no disconnections for occupied households in the last six months. This practice will be extended until the economic situation improves.

    For electricity utilities, from January 2003 to June 2003, there have been a total of 24,786 cases of electricity disconnections. This works out to an average of 4,131 cases per month. The House would be glad to note that households in 1- and 2-room flats make up a very tiny proportion of these disconnection cases. In fact, they constitute only 0.06% of those that have been disconnected. This reflects the fact that such families are helped, to a very large extent, by the various community assistance schemes that are already in place and act as a safety net for them.

    On average, electricity accounts get reconnected after 12 to 15 days. This happens when households make arrangements with SP Services to pay up on their accounts. Households will get reconnected when they pay off their current bill. Previous arrears can then be repaid through instalments.

Working with CDCs

    SP Services takes disconnection of the utilities seriously. Before disconnection, SP Services delivers at least two reminders (pink notices) and a final notice of intended disconnection. SP Services works very closely with the CDCs. When customers inform SP Services that they are facing financial hardship and are unable to make any payments, SP Services will recommend them to their respective CDCs for financial aid.

Deferring Payment for Genuine Hardship Cases

    After CDCs or social agencies have assessed cases as facing genuine hardship, SP Services will not disconnect but allow deferment of payment of the arrears, up to a maximum of three months, until the

Column: 2596

household's financial situation improves. However, households must pay their current charges. This is to prevent a snowballing of debt. At the end of the day, the arrears in utilities charges have to be paid. The crux of the matter is that households in difficulty will have to make attempts to reduce their consumption of electricity and water. Those in hardship should seek assistance either from within their family circle or from the CCCs and CDCs.

    The Government has multiple schemes to help low income households in financial hardship to pay their utility bills. The Rent and Utilities Assistance Scheme (RUAS) helps households renting 1-, 2- and 3-room flats. The Interim Short-Term Financial Assistance Scheme (IFAS) is applicable to households owning 1-, 2-, 3- and 4-room flats. If eligible, the CDCs administering the schemes will help households pay for up to six months of the households' utilities.

Stored Value Metering System

    The stored value meter system which Dr Maliki proposed has in fact been considered in the past. It is a very expensive system. The average cost of a normal electricity meter for individual households is $35. In comparison, a basic stored value metering system will cost about $500 per household. For stored value water metering system, a normal water meter costs an average of $18; a stored value water meter would cost more than $1,500. If the cost of the stored value metering were to be borne by only those households opting for it, it would be an expensive burden for them. If the cost is spread across the whole system, we will be raising the overall system cost and electricity tariffs will have to rise as a result.

    Nevertheless, we will continue to track developments on this and if there are other cost-effective solutions, we will certainly be prepared to re-consider.

    Dr Mohamad Maliki Bin Osman (Sembawang): Sir, point of clarification and supplementary question. The Minister of State mentioned that SP Services is prepared to defer payment of arrears by a

Column: 2597

period of three months if the cases are assessed to be in genuine hardship by the CDCs. The CDCs usually take an average of two months to process a case. Would SP Services withhold any action with regard to disconnection or impending disconnection until the CDCs have completed their investigations and assessments and made their recommendations?

    Dr Vivian Balakrishnan: Sir, once a household has made contact with the relevant agency and is being evaluated, SP Services will not rush in to disconnect. The crux of the point here is to ensure that efforts are being made to moderate usage and to restructure their finances so that this debt can be repaid. As long as genuine attempts are being made in that direction, SP Services has been and will continue to be very forbearing.

Column: 2597

NEW INVESTMENTS AND JOB CREATION
(Strategy and plans)


    4. Mr Gan Kim Yong asked the Minister for Trade and Industry if he will elaborate on (i) his strategy and plans to bring in new investments and create jobs and (ii) the progress made so far.

    The Minister for Trade and Industry (BG George Yong-Boon Yeo): Mr Speaker, Sir, the global economic landscape is changing dramatically. The rise of China, India and other emerging economies has created new challenges for us. The competition for investments has become more intense. But there are also many new opportunities not available to us before. We have therefore to reappraise our strengths and weaknesses in the light of this new situation and reposition ourselves.

    Our strategy to attract investments and create jobs has two components - the external component and the internal component. First, our external strategy is to work for the economic integration of ASEAN, strengthen our linkages to the advanced economies and develop new links to China, India and other emerging economies. To date, we have already

Column: 2598

signed Free Trade Agreements (FTAs) with New Zealand, Japan, the European Free Trade Association, Australia and the US. We are currently negotiating FTAs with Mexico, Canada, India and Jordan. We are also part of the negotiations for an FTA between ASEAN and China. We have commenced negotiations with New Zealand and Chile for a trilateral FTA. We are also likely to start negotiations with South Korea soon.

    Together, these FTAs expand our economic space, improve our connectivity to the major economic centres in the world, and strengthen our position as a major hub for manufacturing and services. Our FTAs complement our Investment Guarantee Agreements and Double Taxation Agreements and reduce the friction to trade and investment.

    The second component of our strategy is internal. There are many things that we have to do to upgrade our capabilities and to improve the efficiency of our economy. These were covered comprehensively by the Economic Review Committee. Let me summarise the four main thrusts.

    First, we must ensure that our infrastructure and factors of production are priced competitively. Corporate and personal income taxes will have to be reduced. Our CPF contributions should be restructured to reduce the statutory burden on employers while meeting basic retirement needs.

    Second, we will develop the services sector as a major growth engine of our economy. The services sector will create jobs both in traditional areas like logistics, ICT, financial services and tourism, as well as in new areas like healthcare, education and the creative industries.

    Third, we have to push for greater creativity and entrepreneurship. We have deep strengths, and our international reputation has never been higher. We need creativity and entrepreneurship to convert our strengths and reputation to economic value. We need many more Singaporeans and Singapore companies

Column: 2599

to exploit new opportunities in the region, China, India, the Middle East, Central Asia and Latin America.

    Fourth, we will upgrade our human capital by investing heavily in the education and training of Singaporeans, and by attracting global talent to Singapore.

    Mr Gan Kim Yong also asked about the progress made in our investment promotion efforts. Notwithstanding the competition and the uncertain global economic environment, EDB has managed to bring in last year manufacturing fixed asset investment (FAI) commitments of S$9 billion, and services total business spending (TBS) commitments of S$2 billion. These investment commitments would create 21,000 jobs when fully implemented.

    In the first half of 2003, EDB secured S$3.7 billion worth of manufacturing FAI commitments, and S$1.1 billion of services total business spending commitments despite SARS. These would create an additional 9,000 jobs. EDB is on track to bringing in S$7.5 billion of manufacturing investment commitments this year and S$1.9 billion of services total business spending commitments for the whole of this year.

    Mr Gan Kim Yong (Holland-Bukit Panjang): The Minister mentioned that one of the strategies was to promote the services sector. Could the Minister give an update on the status of promoting the services sector in Singapore?

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: The three new areas that we identified in the ERC are education, healthcare and the creative industries. Recently, I made a media announcement on our moves to promote education as a growth sector. For healthcare, we will be doing so in the near future. For creative services, I believe MITA is heading this project and some presentations will be made.

    The services sector requires coordination across a number of Ministries, and

Column: 2600

DPM Lee Hsien Loong chairs a Ministerial Committee on the promotion of the services sector to ensure that coordination across Government Ministries and departments is well carried out.

    Mr Gan Kim Yong: Sir, could the Minister give an update on whether any services investments have been brought to Singapore?

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: I do not have the details now but I have just given the total numbers when I referred to total business spending for services investments. They refer to the investment commitments that we have gotten in the services area. We are not doing badly. We are achieving our targets.

Column: 2600

CHANGI AIRPORT
(Competitive advantages)


    5. Mdm Ho Geok Choo asked the Minister for Transport (a) what are the competitive advantages of Changi Airport and (b) what plans and strategies are there for the Airport and its operators, to mount a pre-emptive programme to minimise the impact of competition from the region and to remain the airport of choice.

    The Minister for Transport (Mr Yeo Cheow Tong): Sir, as I had informed Members late last year, my Ministry had reviewed and refined Changi Airport's competitive strategy. Our goal is to anchor our airline partners here, attract more airlines to use Changi Airport and position Singapore for the long haul.

    First, let me stress to Members that an airport does not exist purely on its own merits. What do I mean by this? Let me illustrate. If tomorrow, we are given permission to build an equivalent of a Changi Airport at the South Pole and we offer airlines all the airport services free of charge, can that airport automatically become a hub airport? I think the answer is obviously no. Airports succeed only when there is enough passenger demand in the locality that the airport is located. And airlines will always fly to airports

Column: 2601

where there are passengers to be served. Changi Airport has grown over the years because Singapore is a tourism centre and a regional business hub. The large number of MNCs located here, the significant number of Singapore businessmen and professionals who travel regularly to serve their regional customers, the many Singaporeans who travel abroad each year on holiday and the seven million tourists we attract every year, all add up to a huge base load of air travellers. As long as the base load is here, airlines will continue to serve us regardless of competition from other airports.

    The challenge is how to remain as a key hub airport for the region. Here, connectivity and quality of the airport are vital factors. International airlines that serve the region in a limited way will look for an airport that has a good base load and good connectivity to the key cities and attractions in the region. This allows them to fly into the selected hub airport and distribute their passengers through other airlines to the final destination in the region. They also look for an airport that their passengers will feel comfortable and happy transiting or transferring through.

    In terms of connectivity, Changi Airport ranks very high. Today, Changi Airport serves 63 airlines and is connected to 137 airports in the region and throughout the world. We will continue our efforts to increase Changi's connectivity, both in terms of attracting new airlines as well as actively working with them to serve more destinations. In terms of passenger comfort, Changi Airport enjoys significant competitive advantage through state-of-the-art infrastructure that is managed efficiently and effectively. Passengers using Changi find the speedy clearance, the shopping mall environment, the friendly service and the various passenger facilities provided a very pleasant experience. Many contrast this with the experience in other airports. We therefore coined the term "the Changi Experience" to describe our airport.

    Our lead in terms of comfort and service level, however, has been narrowed in recent years with the building of newer

Column: 2602

regional airports. We must therefore continue to upgrade our facilities, raise productivity, improve operations and enhance our customer orientation. As our competitors catch up, we have to learn from them as well. The Changi Experience is a unique one and we must continually revitalise and enhance it.

    To ensure that Changi remains ahead of our competitors, we have set up a 3-year S$210 million Air Hub Development Fund in January this year. Under the scheme, we have launched a number of initiatives targeted at our industry partners which will further anchor Changi's position as the premier regional air hub. For example, CAAS, the Singapore Tourism Board and various agencies are collaborating with airlines to further stimulate demand for air travel to, through and from Singapore.

    Sir, cost competitiveness is another relevant factor. We will keep our costs competitive by benchmarking internationally and regionally. Where the situation demands it, we have not hesitated to step in early. For example, CAAS was one of the first to introduce a S$45 million SARS relief package and, subsequently, a S$10 million air traffic development scheme. Both schemes help the industry to lower their operating costs. We will continue to look at our cost structure to ensure that our airline partners find it profitable to operate at Changi.

    We have also developed the Airport Logistics Park, or ALPS. Located strategically in Changi's Free Trade Zone, ALPS leverages on the excellent connectivity and superior handling efficiency of Changi Airport. This enables the logistics companies to enjoy rapid turnaround with minimal customs formalities thereby strengthening our position as a leading air logistics hub.

    In preparation for the longer term, I have tasked my Ministry to look at how we can further develop Singapore as an International Aviation Centre. Working with other agencies, our vision is to create a vibrant cluster of aviation and aerospace companies and activities. This will then provide another engine of growth for our

Column: 2603

aviation sector. I can therefore assure Members that my Ministry and the CAAS will proactively ensure that Changi retains its competitive position in the years ahead.

    Mdm Ho Geok Choo (West Coast): Sir, the success of Changi Airport, in short, boils down to satisfaction of passengers and our ability to connect with other airports and anchor airline partners. In the Minister's plan to continue to develop the vibrancy of Changi Airport, how does he propose to incorporate programmes that would continue to enthuse the service providers to continue to deliver excellent service, which is a very important factor in attracting tourists and passengers to come to Singapore?

    Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, the CAAS engages in close consultation with all their airline partners. From these consultations, they get a better understanding of what is needed by not just the airlines but the travel industry as well. So, by having all these dialogue sessions, we are able to formulate programmes to address areas where further improvements are needed. And I think that is how Changi Airport has managed to achieve continual progress, and we will continue to do that.

    Mr R. Ravindran (Marine Parade): Sir, I understand that many domestic airlines in Indonesia and also some of the budget airline operators in the region would like to hub in Singapore. But they are complaining that the cost of hubbing in Singapore is too high. Are we reacting fast enough to ensure that we are able to attract them to hub in Singapore? Or are we going to wait until a situation arises like PSA where we lose the customers and then we take measures to attract them back to Singapore? I would like to get the Minister's input on this.

    Mr Yeo Cheow Tong: Sir, as I explained just now, if the passenger load is here, airlines will want to operate through Singapore. Mr Ravindran mentioned about low-cost airlines wanting to hub here. If he

Column: 2604

knows which of these airlines, please let us know and we will definitely reach out to them.

    Mr Steve Chia Kiah Hong (Non-Constituency Member): Sir, budget airlines like ValuAir said that they want to use Changi Airport as its hub. Social objectives

    The CPF is Singapore's most important social safety net. Its first and principal objective is to provide for the retirement needs of Singaporeans. Later, we added other social objectives like saving for home ownership and healthcare.

An article in the New York Times talked about the possibility of living to 600 years old, because of the promises of genetic medicine. It explained that our organs might break down. But scientists were now breeding special animals that could grow replacement human hearts and lungs. Scientists have also found a chemical in red wine - for those who love red wine, please note - which may slow down ageing.     So from the social perspective, the higher the CPF contribution rate, the better.

    But increasingly, we must also consider the impact of the CPF on our cost competitiveness.

    In the 70s, 80s and 90s, cost competitiveness was not an overriding concern. We had good growth year after year. During those 30 years, we grew by 8% annually. Our salaries too rose by an average of 8% every year. We could afford to put a lot into the CPF.

    Our business costs then were lower than those in developed countries. And we faced limited competition. Many of today's emerging economies were under communist regimes at that time. Others were highly regulated and protectionist. China and India, for instance, were not open and attractive to foreign investments. Singapore, in fact, was one of the earlier and most ardent advocates of an open, MNC-based economy.

    But times have changed. China and India, with a combined population of more than two billion people, have entered the economic race. So too have many other countries, like in Central and Eastern Europe. They are following our MNC-based strategy for economic growth. Their low cost of doing business is extremely attractive to investors.

    On the other hand, the cost of doing business in Singapore has reached First World levels, as has our standard of living.

Cost competitiveness is a key worry for Singapore today.

    Therefore, from the economic perspective, we should keep the CPF contribution rate as low as possible. The lower we go, the less the pressure on companies to move out because of high wage costs. Wages account for as much as 20-30% of total business costs in certain industries.

    This is why we need to retune our CPF scheme - to strike a better balance between our social objectives and our economic concerns.

    We will need to address four aspects of the CPF system: the contribution rates, the salary ceiling, the CPF and Medisave Minimum Sums and the withdrawal at age 55.

CPF contribution rates

    First, the CPF contribution rate.

    The CPF rate is currently 36%: 20% from the employee and 16% from the employer. The Government had intended to restore the CPF rate to 40% when economic conditions permit.

    But looking forward to the future competitive environment, this is no longer advisable. It would price us out of the market. We would lose more jobs. We should give up the 40% target, to save jobs.

    The Government did not rush into this decision. We struggled between our commitment to restore the CPF rate to 40% and the economic reality. You see, the trust between the people and the Government is paramount. It is the basis upon which we have carried out many tough but necessary measures to improve the lives of our people. It is therefore not an easy decision for the Government to give up a commitment it has made. It risks breaking the trust between the people and the Government.

    But we have no choice. If investors think that we are going to restore the 40% rate in the future, they will factor this into their cost calculations. They may not come. Even those who are here may make plans to move out to cheaper locations.

    I hope Singaporeans understand why we are not restoring the 40% contribution rate. Our priority must be to save jobs for our people.

Longer term variable rate of 30-36%

    The question is: what CPF contribution rate is appropriate?

    Nowadays, the world economy changes rapidly. It is not practical to try to identify a single number as a long-term rate. No one can be sure how the competitive situation will evolve. We must also expect our economy to run into rough weather from time to time. We should thus make our system flexible, so that we can put more into the CPF in good years and cut the rate in bad years. This will give us room to respond quickly to the changing economic environment.

    I feel, therefore, that it is better to set an upper limit and a lower limit for the CPF contribution rate for the long-term, instead of a single rate.

    We will not have any formula to decide what the actual CPF rate should be at any point in time. We will look at the prevailing economic conditions, and assess accordingly. If there is to be a rise or cut in the rate, we will give as much notice as possible, to allow for advance planning. I do not envisage fine-tuning the rate every year.     Let me move on to the CPF salary ceiling. The ERC established the principle that the CPF scheme should focus on workers earning between the 10th and 80th percentile incomes.

After acknowledging the problem, the bitter medicine may need to be taken over a period of time, and there may need to be more than one medicine with a bitter after-taste, no matter how sugar-coated. And after that, the patient may still need rehabilitation and physiotherapy to recover the use of flabby muscles, stiff joints and maybe a flabby mind. Some medicine may appear to be less painful but may not be so effective. Just as no physician can do a good job if he has an uncooperative patient, I fear that the Government's fiscal measures and CPF retuning will not bear fruits unless Singaporeans acknowledge that we as a people and a country need to recognise we have a problem in competitiveness and take all necessary steps to address the matter.

    Other MPs have spoken about the steps that the Government may need to take, but I would like to focus a little bit differently and say that the onus is now upon our people - our workers - to recognise the steps that the Government has done and to take their own steps to recognise the problem. My grassroots leaders still keep telling me how difficult it is to recruit

Column: 2697

waiters and waitresses, even when the pay is $1,200 a month. Singaporeans, it seems, are not prepared to put up with split shifts and having to work on weekends. Other grassroots leaders tell me about difficulties with recruiting for shipyards, even when they are prepared to offer training. And when our Town Council decided to employ more Singaporean workers for cleansing operations, residents started complaining that actually local workers were spraying water and not scrubbing, unlike some of the foreign workers. When the water dries up, the corridors are still dirty.

    As we upskill the younger and more educated workers, I think the only way for us to maintain low unemployment for older and less educated workers is for them to accept the manual service and less convenient jobs that are currently being taken by some of our foreign workers. I think we need to relearn the dignity of honest manual labour. We can outsource a lot of jobs, but certain jobs cannot be easily outsourced and have to be done in the country and onsite. I do not think there is any shame in honest labour, even when some aspects of the job may be a bit demeaning. As doctors and healthcare professionals, this is the creed which doctors and nurses have to learn to accept - unpleasant sights and smells, and sometimes unreasonable behaviour of people who are ill and need our help. I do not think people think any less of our profession for the fact that we have to deal with all these unpleasant things.

    I call upon the Government to have a campaign to change societal values, to re-emphasise the dignity of labour, the principle that any job is better than no job, and it is better to be at least partially employed and to receive some help financially than to look out for handouts alone. We manage to change Singaporeans' attitude to a military career, and I think we can do the same for manual labour and service sector jobs. Having misplaced pride and a handout mentality would not be good for us in the long term.

    The effect of CPF cuts would be to lower our labour cost and make our labour more

Column: 2698

competitive. However, cost alone is not only the issue. Our products, as a whole, as a country, have to be cheaper and better, or at least give better value for the price. Factories in China, India and the former Eastern bloc have found out that when cheaper and better quality foreign goods started appearing in their markets, discounting obsolescent product lines alone did not ensure sales.

    As a potential employee, if what you have to offer is a set of old-fashioned and limited skills do not expect an easy time on the market for new jobs. Singaporeans like ai pea ai chi. Your potential employer is also looking for a better, cheaper, more reliable labour product, just as you want to have it cheaper and better. Many of our citizens decry the fact that many employers would like to have people to have facility in Chinese or other languages. Others find that employers want to have good looking frontline staff. Instead of complaining that people are discriminating against you, perhaps we should learn to give employers what they want. If you read in today's papers, people in the call centres are now learning how to speak American English so that they are actually able to do a better job even when they are far away from sight.

    In the same way that many older workers embrace computers to deal with marketplace realities, I think the CDCs can help non-Chinese Singaporeans get a working knowledge of Mandarin to make them more employable. The MPs who are not so good in Mandarin manage to learn a bit more too.

    If you want a frontline counter job, you might want to attend a course that helps you project the pleasant personality and good inter-personal skills and also gives tips on dressing right. If you look frumpy and you sound grumpy, do not blame people for not giving you the job. Again, CDCs can help in this regard.

    The last bit is just a suggestion for HDB. As we have asked the people to cut their cloth as they are able to afford it, and cut their clothes according to what they can afford, perhaps now we are actually

Column: 2699

asking people to live more within their means. People who are downgrading and unable to service large housing loans need to be looking at cheaper alternatives. Between a highly subsidised rental market with arguably lots of necessary restrictions and the free market, I think a lot of people in distress would really look forward to an alternative where HDB will have minimally subsidised rental flats which are maybe a bit bigger but which would fill the need or gap, much in the same way that NTUC FairPrice supermarkets manage to moderate prices. Perhaps, that is one practical measure that would help many hard-pressed Singaporeans.

    On this note, Sir, I support the statement.

that we face as a nation. We must therefore brace ourselves for the needed changes to remain competitive in a very fast changing world. constituencies to effect a nation-wide unemployment registration exercise. We should go overseas to promote our incentive

Column: 2702

packages. Only then, can we link up with the foreign entrepreneurs, persuade them to bring their investments here, and create more job opportunities for our people.

    Thirdly, we should adapt to changes. No industry can prosper forever and in every industry, there will be ups and downs. Prior to the 60s, Singapore's main output was in farming and agricultural produce. In the 60s and 70s, we promoted industrialisation and concentrated on labour-intensive industries. In the 80s and 90s, we moved towards high value-added industries which paid higher wages, and our people enjoyed better standard of living. That has resulted in a very high wage level in Singapore today, where the labour cost is significantly higher than the other countries in this region. I asked them where they would like to go for further studies

after their graduation. They named four destinations - Canada, United States, England and Singapore. Singapore has a very good brand that is well known overseas. We should make use of this foundation to expand and improve our university education. We should seize this opportunity. We should not wait. Column: 2704

of these windfall savings to help their workers. So, I suggest that those companies which are making profits should set aside at least 1% as a training or welfare fund for the workers. This would enable the workers to share the windfall.

    Fifthly, we should change the work attitude of our workers so that they can keep up with the times. Even in the hawker centres and factories, it is the same. So, I think our workers should be more realistic. They should enrich themselves and make some compromises and be more flexible. Only then can they survive in this ever-changing environment and be self-reliant.

    Let me quote an example. When I completed my secondary school, I wanted to go to the university. I was worried that my family could not support me for my university education. Column: 2705

a conscientious worker and was also an undergraduate. He recognised my efforts and promoted me to be a quality inspector, and my wages were raised from $2.50 to $3.50 an hour.
